So Teresa and Antoinette, thanks for coming on.
You're welcome.
You're welcome.
So Teresa, tell us just quickly why you were sent to prison.
Well, it was a long custody battle with my common-law husband.
We weren't married but we had lived together.
And he had stalked me and broken into five of my homes and stoled all my belongings.
And he had physically abused me and I had police reports of it.
But the crime happened behind a custody battle and that was what the - why I just crashed in.
I was supposed to give him my son the following day, and he was five years old.
And we had a long custody battle and I'd tried to kill him the night before I had to give him my son.
And he was shot 47 times.

I was in the car when it happened, and I was addicted to Zanex.

No.

Thirty-eight years ago, researchers from the New England Aquarium started studying North Atlantic right whales off the coast of eastern Maine.
Large pods of the whales showed up like clockwork in late summer.
Now those endangered whales come to that area only sporadically, and more and more, they're being seen far to the north.
Murray Carpenter went out on a research vessel to learn more.

It's just after dawn, and Amy Knowlton is surveying the waters of the Bay of Fundy, just off of easternmost Maine.
She's a scientist with the New England Aquarium's Anderson Cabot Center for Ocean Life.
She points out harbor porpoises chasing fish near the boat.
And then something much larger appears in the windswept water.
Whale behind us - it's probably a humpback or a fin whale.
We'll get a better look.
It turns out to be two humpbacks.
One spouts near the boat.

It's a cool sighting, but these are not the whales she's after.
Knowlton is hoping to find the North Atlantic right whales that she and her colleagues have been studying here since 1980.
They're large baleen whales, with big heads and no dorsal fins.
Researchers used to count as many as 200 foraging here in late summer.
But they became scarce starting in 2010, and their range shifted dramatically.
Many more of the whales are now summering hundreds of miles north, in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence.
Mariana Hagbloom, one of Knowlton's research assistants, surveyed that area in August and said it was nothing like the Bay of Fundy.
We had days where we were seeing about 50 individuals, working them from the boat and just right whales popping up left and right.
It was a beautiful thing to see.
But in total, fewer than 450 North Atlantic right whales remain, and their numbers have been falling for a decade as more have been entangled in fishing gear or killed by ships.
Reproduction has also declined.
Researchers found no new calves last winter.
With the population on edge, scientists want to understand the reasons for the new migration pattern.
Nick Record is with the Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences in East Boothbay, Maine.
My hypothesis is that this change in the migration patterns of whales is connected to their food resource, mainly Calanus.
Calanus is like the battery of the Gulf of Maine.
Calanus is a type of fat-rich plankton that's favored by many species.
Record says the changing climate is not only rapidly warming the region's waters.
It's also shifting the currents that once swept this important plankton into the deep basins where right whales feed, making it less available to them.
Moira Brown, another scientist with the New England Aquarium team, says she actually finds hope in the habitat shift, all the way from the waters near Maine to the Gulf of Saint Lawrence.
